blocks.text:
Today, in the year 2038, we have mastered the great crises. It was close, but we made it. The global ecological, social and economic disasters of the 2020s brought people, states, institutions and companies together. They committed themselves to fundamental rights and jointly created viable, adaptable systems and legal frameworks on a planetary basis, giving decentralised, local structures the space to maintain and create highly diverse models of co-existing.

Technology and big data helped us to turn new and old ideas into reality. And often architects were part of the solution because they had answers instead of coming up with more questions. Drama is now history. We live in a radical democracy, in a radical bureaucracy. On a planet that doesn't know or need heroes or villains.
blocks.text2: German Pavilion at the 17th International Architecture Exhibition — La Biennale di Venezia

blocks.text: with Diana Alvarez-Marin, Baubotanik, Francesca Bria, Ludwig Engel, Sename Koffi Agbodjinou, Lucy Lobster, Sabine Oberhuber & Thomas Rau, Joanna Pope, Rebiennale / R3B, Leif Randt, Audrey Tang, Cassie Thornton, Mark Wigley, Anna Yeboah and many more

Man kann sagen, dass dieser Pavillon einer der optimistischsten ist, die es je gab, eben weil nicht nur behauptet wird, dass man eventuell Ideen für mögliche Lösungen habe, sondern aus der Zukunft verfügt und erklärt wird, dass und wie diese Lösungen funktioniert haben.
decoding social relations
This is what we call {permanent BETA}, a digital contract between individuals that is constantly updated and re-invented because it is never finished.

We know from social scientists that a diverse group of people can make very good decisions. We also know from a number of recent experiments that citizens can be called upon to make decisions on very tough policy issues, including climate change, and even to shape constitutions. Finally, we can draw from the past for inspiration on how to actually build citizen-run institutions.
Citizens' collective intelligence is part of the decision making processes that are happening at our town halls.
Audrey Tang, 2038
The digital was crucial for finding better ways to facilitate dialogue and work toward common understandings between different actors and groups.
enacting disownership
This new world exists only so long as transnational solidarity exists, allowing processes of cooperation and autonomous self-determination to keep unfolding.

frontmatter.text: „For those who never experienced a change of the political system, it seemed unimaginable. But it happened and it could happen agan.“

blocks.text: The crisis has shown us how little capitalism has done for so many people and that other ways of living and working are possible.

Today, private property is no longer a viable basis for social organization, neither in terms of the human social system, which used to be dominated by the market and the commerce, nor in terms of the environment.
Evgeny Morozov, 2038
What we actually achieved, post-crisis, was the development of a society not obsessed with competition.
reconnecting ecosystems
„A new design has emerged: one that treats buildings as a raw material stock for the future.“
Today, green investment options are plentiful. Renewable energy is cheaper than coal almost everywhere in the world, and increasingly competitive with gas.
A circular economy is focused on designing out waste and pollution, keeping products and materials in use, and regenerating natural systems, so that we do not exhaust the resources of our planet.
blocks.text2: Naoko Ishii & Frans van Houten, WEF

blocks.text: The central premise is simple: the goal of economic activity should be about meeting the core needs of all but within the means of the planet. The “doughnut” is a device to show what this means in practice. (...) recognise the need for national government and supranational authorities to get on board.
A designer is more like a gardener, deciding the direction and not the form, thinking of a process, of different possibilities of different future.
Caroline Nevejan, 2038
We created {legal entities} around natural living forms {that are not human},  natural elements, {crucial for the survival of the planet}, have rights.
architecting time & space
Non-human agents and matter become active political agents, co-authoring the design project.
news here
Any idea you have about the future cannot be the future, because the future is by definition what exceeds your ideas.
Jennifer Jacquet & Becca Franks and some other species, 2038
"It's one of those things that you look back on, and you think "How could we have done that for so long?"
NEWS
Alexander Russ quote here
Fabian Peter
Üblicherweise versuchen wir, aus der Gegenwart heraus eine Zukunft zu entwerfen. Jetzt drehen wir die Blickrichtung um und schauen aus einer gedachten Zukunft zurück auf die Gegenwart.
